VR252370_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately include either of the following criteria.
o.af:
Example Response:

The initial momentum of the marble-cannon system is zero, so it will be zero after the marble is launched as well. A greater marble speed then means that the backward cannon speed is greater. Since the acceleration due to friction is the same regardless of cannon speed, a greater cannon speed means that the cannon will slide a greater distance.

OR

While the marble is in the cannon, the force on the marble has the same magnitude as the force on the cannon (according to Newton’s 3rd law). If the mass of the marble stays constant but the final speed of the marble increases, the net force on the marble must increase (according to Newton’s 2nd law) and, therefore, the net force on the cannon must increase as well (the force of friction remains constant) giving the cannon a larger final speed resulting in a greater distance.

By conservation of momentum, mass and velocity are inversely proportional. Since velocity is squared when determining kinetic energy, a greater speed increases the kinetic energy by a larger factor than a smaller mass decreases the energy.

OR

The cannon and marble exert forces of equal magnitude on each other. However, the marble will move a greater distance than the cannon while these forces are exerted. So, the marble has more work done on it, and therefore a greater kinetic energy.

VR252372_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately include either of the following criteria.
o.af:
Example Response:

The initial momentum of the marble-cannon system is zero, so it will be zero after the marble is launched as well. A greater marble mass then means that the backward cannon speed is greater. Since the acceleration due to friction is the same regardless of cannon speed, a greater cannon speed means that the cannon will slide a greater distance.

OR

While the marble is in the cannon, the force on the marble has the same magnitude as the force on the cannon (according to Newton’s 3rd law). If the final speed of the marble is the same each time but the mass of the marble increases, the net force on the marble must increase (according to Newton’s 2nd law) and, therefore, the net force on the cannon must increase as well (the force of friction remains constant) giving the cannon a larger final speed resulting in a greater distance.

OR

While the string is being pulled, both tops will experience the same torque and rotate through the same angular displacement. According to the rotational analogue of Newton’s second law, the top with greater rotational inertia will experience less angular acceleration. Lower angular acceleration through the same displacement means a lower angular speed.

VR368258_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately include any of the following criteria:
o.af:
Example Response:

If the collision between the ball and the floor were elastic, the speed just before the ball hits would be equal to the speed of the ball just after it leaves the floor. Because of conservation of energy, since air resistance is negligible, if the speed before and after the collision were the same the ball should return to its starting height. Because it returns to a lower height, we must conclude that there was energy lost in the collision, making the collision inelastic.

Example Response:

Both bars experience the same torque because they experience the same force at the same distance from the pivot. Change in angular momentum is equal to torque times time, so since the two bars have the same torque exerted for the same time, the two bars have the same change in angular momentum from t=0 to t= t 1 .

o.af:
Scoring note: If the wrong answer is selected, the response is not graded.

Example Response:

The objects exerted torques in opposite directions, with object 1 exerting a larger torque, so object 1 determines the net torque direction. With the torque from object 1 removed, the net torque and angular acceleration switch direction (becoming clockwise) to the torque from object 2. The angular velocity does not change direction immediately and is still counterclockwise.

Example Response

The net force exerted on the block is larger since there is no frictional force from the surface. The net force is related to the acceleration, so since the block has a larger net force it will have a larger acceleration. Both the block and the disk start from rest and have to travel the same distance, and since the block has a larger acceleration, it will be able to travel the distance in a smaller time. Therefore, the block will reach the bottom in less time.

Example Response

The student’s claim is incorrect. There is always a force of gravity exerted on the sphere, this means that in order for the sphere to be in equilibrium in the vertical direction there must always be a component of the force of tension balancing the force of gravity. This means that the string can never be horizontal.

Example Response

In both cases, the original energy stored in the spring is the same, so the kinetic energy at x=0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaaguart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=xfr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaGaamiEaiabg2da9iaaicdaaaa@38B0@ is the same. The larger mass block will have a larger normal force exerted by the surface so it will have a larger force of kinetic friction exerted on it by the surface. Because the energy dissipated by friction must be the same, the greater frictional force on the second block brings the second block to rest after traveling a shorter distance.

VR830458_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately include any of the following criteria.
o.af:
Example Response

With a fluid of larger density, the buoyant force exerted by the fluid on the sphere is larger. The weight of the sphere is the same, so the net force exerted on the sphere is greater. With the same mass of sphere and a larger net force the acceleration is larger. With a larger acceleration and the same distance to travel, the time to travel that distance is smaller, so t 1 > t 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E3B@ .

VR830551_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately include any of the following criteria.
o.af:
Example Response

Fill the container with liquid. Put the container on the table and release the liquid from the hole. Measure the height of the hole and the horizontal distance from the container to where the liquid lands on the floor. Fill the container again and place it on a single book. Release the liquid from the hole again and measure the height of the hole above the floor and the horizontal distance from the container to the place on the floor where the liquid lands. Repeat using more books to reduce experimental uncertainty.

o.d: The response does not accurately include any of the following criteria.
o.af:
Example response

The bounce dart results in the greatest maximum height for the sphere. When the dart and sphere collide, the change in momentum of the sphere is equal in magnitude to the change in momentum of the dart, but in the opposite direction. Since the bounce dart is the only dart moving to the left after the collision, it is the only dart with a momentum changed greater than m d v 0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3CEC@ , so the initial momentum and speed is greatest for the sphere hit by the bounce dart. Because it has the greatest initial speed, this sphere will reach the greatest final height.

For 0<t< t 1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E97@ :

Δx=area under velocity graph= 1 2 t 1 p max m MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5BF4@

For t 1 <t<1.5 t 1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@41F3@ :

Δx=area= 1 2 ( t 1 2 ) p max m = 1 4 t 1 p max m MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5505@

For t>1.5 t 1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3F09@ , the velocity is zero so the displacement is zero.

Add the displacements:

Δ x f = 1 2 t 1 p max m + 1 4 t 1 p max m = 3 4 t 1 p max m MathType@MTEF@5@5@@587E@

Δx= v avg Δt=( 1 2 )( p max m )( 3 2 t 1 )       = 3 4 t 1 p max m MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5F15@

The cart stops moving at t=1.5 t 1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3F07@ , so

Δ x f = 3 4 t 1 p max m MathType@MTEF@5@5@@45B0@ .

o.af:
Example Response:

The pivot force would be directly to the right. Neither of the other forces (gravitational and string forces) exert a torque about the center of mass, and the net torque about the center of mass must be zero, so the pivot force will not exert a torque about the center of mass. This can only happen if the pivot force is zero or directed toward the center of mass. The pivot force must be nonzero to balance the horizontal component of the string force, so it is now to the right.

Alternative Response:

The pivot force will be reduced in size. At the new location, and with the axis of rotation set at the pivot point, the torque from the tension exactly balances the torque from gravity. The position vector is the same for each force, thus, the vertical component of tension is now equal to the weight of the bar, which makes the new tension half the original tension and eliminates the need for a vertical component of F P MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGgbWaaSbaaSqaaiaadcfaaeqaaaaa@3AC8@ . The horizontal component of F P MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGgbWaaSbaaSqaaiaadcfaaeqaaaaa@3AC8@ , F Px MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGgbWaaSbaaSqaaiaadcfacaWG4baabeaaaaa@3BC5@ balances the horizontal component of the tension, so it is also halved.

VR864815_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately include any of the following criteria.
o.af:
Example Response 1:

Use the force probe to pull the string with a steady force and note the force probe reading. Use a stopwatch to measure the time it takes the disk to turn 5 revolutions. Repeat the procedure for a total of 5 trials, pulling with a different amount of force for each trial.

Example Response 2:

1. Start two stopwatches and use the force probe to pull the string with a steady force. Note the force probe reading.

2. After several seconds, stop pulling and record the time on one stopwatch.

3. Wait for the disk to stop spinning. Record the time at which the disk stops on the second stopwatch.

4. Repeat steps 1 through 3 for a total of 5 trials, pulling with a different amount of force for each trial.

VR864856_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately include any of the following criteria.
o.af:
Example Response

Selection: α A < α E MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C53@

Since the cylinder is the same distance from the pivot point in both trials, the torque from the cylinder’s weight has the same magnitude but will be in opposite directions. In the first trial, the weights of the cylinder and the bar cause torques in opposite directions, so the net torque is the difference in their magnitudes. In the second trial, the cylinder and bar weights cause torques in the same direction (clockwise), so the net torque is the sum of their magnitudes and is greater than in the first trial. The rotational inertia is the same in both trials because the cylinder is the same distance from the peg, so the greater torque in the second trial means that the angular acceleration is greater in the second trial.

o.af:
Example Response

The student’s claim is incorrect. The mechanical energy of a block-spring system is equal to the elastic potential energy of the system at the maximum displacement: E= U s,max = 1 2 k A 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4584@ . Because the springs are identical and the block-spring systems each oscillate with the same amplitude, the energy of each system will be the same. Therefore, the maximum kinetic energy (which occurs when the elastic potential energy is zero), will also be the same for each block.

Example Response 1 (Using the velocity graph in Figure 4)

They are consistent. The velocity graph in part (c) shows that the velocity is zero at 0.8 h max MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3F17@ and h max MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3CE9@ , so the block’s kinetic energy does not change. This means the net work on the block is zero, consistent with my answer in part (b).

Example Response 2 (Using the acceleration graph in Figure 5)

They are consistent. Net force is proportional to acceleration, so the area under a net force graph would be zero like it is for the acceleration graph I drew in part (c) because of symmetry. This area (for the net force graph) equals the net work done on the block, which is therefore zero as I said in part (b).

VR870188_rubric_category_3.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately include any of the following criteria.
o.af:
Example Response 1

Selection: It is consistent.

The graph indicates that kinetic energy decreases as the moon’s distance increases. This means that negative work is being done on the moon when it is moving farther from the planet. In part (a), the net force direction is the acceleration direction, and has a component in the opposite direction of the velocity, so negative work is being done and the kinetic energy should be decreasing, consistent with the graph.

Example Response 2

VR870648_rubric_category_0.s: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

o.d: The response does not accurately include any of the following criteria.
o.af:
Example Response

Selection: ω f < ω i MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FD5@

Because there are no external torques on the disk-person system, the angular momentum of the system is constant. As the person walks to the edge of the rotating disk, the rotational inertia of the system increases. As a result, the angular velocity of the system must decrease to maintain a constant angular momentum.
